story.title: Our Story
story.para1: Founded in 2020, AJD NGANJ emerged from a grassroots movement of concerned citizens who believed that politics should serve the people, not special interests. What started as community gatherings in local halls has grown into a nationwide political force representing millions of voices.
story.para2: Our journey has been marked by unwavering commitment to democratic principles, transparent governance, and the belief that every citizen deserves a voice in shaping their nation's future. We've challenged the status quo and proven that people-powered politics can create real change.

vision.title: Our Vision
vision.description: To build a nation where every citizen has equal opportunities to prosper, where governance is transparent and accountable, and where the collective good always takes precedence over individual interests. We envision a society driven by justice, equality, and sustainable progress.

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.description: To empower citizens through inclusive political participation, implement policies that address real-world challenges, and create a government that truly represents and serves all people. We are committed to fighting corruption, promoting education, and ensuring economic opportunities for all.

values.title: Our Core Values
values.integrityDesc: We maintain the highest standards of honesty and ethical conduct in all our actions. Transparency isn't just a promise—it's our foundation.
values.accountabilityDesc: We are answerable to our commitments and to the people we serve.
values.inclusivityDesc: Every voice matters, regardless of background, religion, or economic status. We celebrate diversity and ensure everyone has a seat at the table.
values.innovationDesc: We embrace progressive ideas and modern solutions to age-old problems, always looking forward to build a better tomorrow.

leader1.name: Mia Moshiuzzaman
leader1.bio: The current Convenor of Aamjanata Dol is Colonel (Retd.) Mia Mashiuzzaman. He contested the first party election for the post of President and secured a landslide victory. He was elected President by receiving a total of 95 votes. His sole defeated rival was Mr. Mohammad Shoikot, who managed to receive only 3 votes. This huge margin of victory proves his strong acceptance and leadership capability within the party. He is currently leading the party as its Convenor.

leader2.name: Tarek Rahman
leader2.bio: The current General Secretary of Aamjanata Dol is Tarek Rahman. He is a well-known political figure in various popular movements across the country. He contested the first party election for General Secretary and won by a large margin. In that election, he was elected after receiving 93 votes. His sole defeated rival was Mohammad Mostofa, who received only 5 votes. He is currently managing the party's important organizational activities.

leader3.name: Jonab Arif Billah
leader3.bio: Organizational Secretary of Amjonatar Dal. He was defeated in the first election for this post. In that election, Faysal Ahmed was elected as the Organizational Secretary with 60 votes. The defeated candidates were Arif Billah (who received 34 votes) and Dr. Anamul Hoque (who received 4 votes). Subsequently, when the elected Organizational Secretary Faysal Ahmed left the party, Arif Billah was appointed as the new Organizational Secretary.

intro.title: Our Commitment to You
intro.para1: This manifesto represents more than political promises—it's a sacred contract between AJD NGANJ and the people we serve. Every policy outlined here has been developed through extensive consultation with citizens, experts, and community leaders across our nation.
intro.para2: We believe in evidence-based policymaking, sustainable development, and inclusive growth. Our vision is clear: to build a nation where opportunity is universal, where justice is blind, and where every citizen can achieve their full potential.

principles.title: Core Principles of Amjonatar Dal
principles.subtitle: The core principles of Amjonatar Dal are Sovereignty, Self-reliance, and Good Governance. These three principles will guide the structure and objectives of Amjonatar Dal. The following explanations are defined in support of the three principles:

sovereignty.title: 1. Sovereignty
sovereignty.description: Bangladesh's sovereignty means our country's independence and our ability to make our own decisions. It ensures that we will not allow foreign interference in our internal and external affairs and that our country will be governed according to our own laws and policies. By pledging to protect sovereignty, we will protect our beloved motherland from political, economic, cultural, military and social aggression.

selfReliance.title: 2. Self-reliance
selfReliance.description: We will strive to achieve self-reliance through our own resources and capabilities in Bangladesh's economic and social development. Our strong efforts will be on creating employment for the people of the country, developing local industries and increasing the ability to compete in the international market.

goodGovernance.title: 3. Good Governance
goodGovernance.description: We will fight to establish good governance through transparency, accountability and justice in running the government. Through establishing good governance, we will ensure that all activities of the state are being conducted for the welfare of the people and the rights of all levels of people are being protected.

gender.point2: Rights consistent with religious and social values
gender.point3: Effective laws to prevent violence against women and children
gender.point4: Respect for men's social and paternal responsibilities and rights

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.q1: How will these initiatives be funded?
faq.a1: Our funding strategy combines progressive taxation, efficient resource allocation, public-private partnerships, and elimination of wasteful spending. We've conducted comprehensive fiscal analysis ensuring all programs are financially sustainable without increasing the deficit.
faq.a2: Unlike traditional manifestos, ours includes specific timelines, measurable targets, and accountability mechanisms. We've committed to quarterly progress reports and independent audits to ensure transparency and track our performance.
faq.q3: How can citizens participate in implementation?
faq.a3: We believe in participatory governance. Citizens can join policy committees, attend town halls, provide feedback through digital platforms, and volunteer for community initiatives. Every voice matters in shaping our collective future.
faq.q4: What about rural and marginalized communities?
faq.a4: Special focus is given to bridging the urban-rural divide. We've allocated 40% of development funds specifically for rural areas and marginalized communities, ensuring equitable growth and opportunity for all citizens.

q1.situation: A major factory in your town is closing down. The owner wants to sell it to a foreign corporation, but workers are demanding the government take it over to save jobs.

a.text: The owner has every right to sell - it's their property and their decision

b.text: The government should step in and nationalize it to protect workers' livelihoods

c.text: Workers should be given the first option to buy and run it as a cooperative

d.text: Let the market decide - if the business isn't profitable, it shouldn't be artificially kept alive

q2.situation: Cheap imported clothing is flooding local markets, causing local textile workers to lose jobs. What should be done?

a.text: Impose heavy tariffs on imports to protect local industry

b.text: Allow free trade - consumers deserve affordable options and the market will adapt

c.text: Provide retraining programs for workers while gradually reducing protections

d.text: Ban all textile imports and focus only on domestic production

q3.situation: During an economic recession, the government is deciding how to respond. What approach do you support?

a.text: Government should spend heavily on infrastructure and social programs to stimulate the economy

b.text: Government should cut spending and taxes, letting the private sector lead recovery

c.text: Do nothing - recessions are natural cycles that correct themselves

d.text: Focus on supporting small businesses and local enterprises specifically

q4.situation: Your city's water supply is managed by a government agency that's inefficient and poorly maintained. A private company offers to take over.

a.text: Accept privatization - private companies are more efficient and accountable

b.text: Keep it public - water is a basic right that shouldn't be profit-driven

c.text: Create a public-private partnership with strict government oversight

d.text: Reform the public agency instead of handing over essential services

q5.situation: A new policy proposes that all major economic decisions should be made jointly by business leaders, government officials, and union representatives.

a.text: Good idea - cooperation between all stakeholders leads to better outcomes

b.text: Workers' unions alone should have more decision-making power

c.text: Business owners should make their own decisions without interference

d.text: Only elected representatives should make economic policy

q6.situation: Your country is facing a crisis. Some argue for a strong leader with emergency powers, others want to maintain democratic processes despite slower decision-making.

a.text: Democracy must be preserved even if it's slower - no one should have absolute power

b.text: A temporary strong leader is needed to handle the crisis effectively

c.text: Form a coalition government representing all major groups

d.text: Let experts and technocrats handle it, not politicians

q7.situation: The head of state position in your country is being debated. What system do you prefer?

a.text: An elected president who serves limited terms

b.text: A constitutional monarch who serves as a unifying figurehead

c.text: A parliamentary system where the prime minister leads

d.text: Direct democracy where citizens vote on all major decisions

q8.situation: A complex policy about nuclear energy needs to be decided. Scientists recommend one path, but public opinion strongly opposes it.

a.text: Follow the scientists' recommendation - experts know best

b.text: Follow public opinion - democracy means listening to the people

c.text: Educate the public first, then hold a referendum

d.text: Let elected representatives decide after consulting both sides

q9.situation: Government positions should be filled based on:

a.text: Merit and qualifications alone - the best person for the job

b.text: A combination of merit and ensuring representation from all backgrounds

c.text: Family connections and social standing have always worked

d.text: Random selection from qualified candidates to prevent corruption

q10.situation: The government proposes extensive surveillance to prevent crime and terrorism. How do you feel?

a.text: Security is worth some privacy loss - protect the nation at all costs

b.text: Absolutely not - this is a step toward totalitarianism

c.text: Only with strict judicial oversight and transparency

d.text: Communities should self-govern without any central authority

q11.situation: A new law would require everyone to participate in community service programs. What's your view?

a.text: Oppose - individuals should choose how to spend their time

b.text: Support - community cohesion requires everyone to contribute

c.text: Support with exemptions for those with valid reasons

d.text: Let communities decide their own requirements locally

q12.situation: A religious group wants their moral code to become the basis for national laws. Your position?

a.text: Religion and state must be completely separate

b.text: Religious values can inform laws but not dictate them

c.text: The majority religion's values should guide legislation

d.text: Each community should be able to follow its own religious laws

q13.situation: Traditional gender roles are being challenged in schools and workplaces. What approach should society take?

a.text: Actively promote change and new definitions of gender roles

b.text: Preserve traditional values that have worked for generations

c.text: Let individuals decide without pushing any particular view

d.text: Gradual change through education and dialogue

q14.situation: A wealthy businessman wants to fund a private hospital that would only serve those who can pay premium prices.

a.text: Allow it - economic freedom includes healthcare choices

b.text: Deny it - healthcare should be equal for all, not tiered by wealth

c.text: Allow it only if they also fund free care for the poor

d.text: The government should control all healthcare facilities

q15.situation: Immigrants in your country want to maintain their traditional festivals and languages in public spaces.

a.text: Encourage cultural diversity - it enriches society

b.text: They should assimilate to the local culture in public

c.text: Private cultural expression is fine, but official matters should use local customs

d.text: Each community should have autonomy to maintain its culture

q16.situation: An international organization wants your country to follow global environmental standards that would hurt local industries.

a.text: Accept - global cooperation is essential for planetary survival

b.text: Reject - national interests should come first

c.text: Negotiate for exemptions while supporting the overall goal

d.text: Propose alternative standards that balance both concerns

q17.situation: Some regions in your country want more autonomy to make their own laws and keep more tax revenue locally.

a.text: Support federalism - local governments understand local needs better

b.text: Oppose - a strong central government ensures equality and unity

c.text: Some autonomy on cultural matters, but economic policy should be national

d.text: Full independence for any region that wants it

q18.situation: A neighboring country is experiencing a civil war with human rights abuses. What should your country do?

a.text: Intervene to stop the abuses - we have a moral obligation

b.text: Stay out completely - it's not our business and intervention causes more problems

c.text: Provide humanitarian aid but no military involvement

d.text: Work through international organizations only

q19.situation: Military spending is being debated in parliament. What's your position?

a.text: Increase spending - a strong military ensures peace through strength

b.text: Decrease spending - invest in education and healthcare instead

c.text: Maintain current levels with focus on defense, not offense

d.text: Abolish the military entirely and invest in diplomacy

q20.situation: A smaller nation wants independence from a larger one. The larger nation refuses. Your view?

a.text: Every people has the right to self-determination and independence

b.text: Territorial integrity of nations should be preserved

c.text: Negotiate for greater autonomy within the existing structure

d.text: International community should decide based on the situation
